{{EngvarB|date=January 2019}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Nathaniel Clyne | image = Nathaniel Clyne Southampton FC Manchester United 2012,13.png | image_size = 200 | caption = Clyne with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012 | fullname = Nathaniel Edwin Clyne{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|4|5|df=y}}{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |year=2010 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=87}} | birth_place = [[Stockwell]], England | height = {{height|ft=5|in=9}} | position = [[Right back]] | currentclub = [[AFC Bournemouth]]
(on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = 23 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Afewee Academy{{cite news |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=The Brixton volunteers who made Nathaniel Clyne an England player |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/oct/07/nathaniel-clyne-england-debut-brixton-volunteers |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=27 November 2014 |date=7 October 2014}} | youthyears2 = 1999–2008 | youthclubs2 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | years1 = 2008–2012 | clubs1 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | caps1 = 122 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2012–2015 | clubs2 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps2 = 94 | goals2 = 3 | years3 = 2015– | clubs3 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps3 = 77 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2019– | clubs4 = → [[AFC Bournemouth]] (loan) | caps4 = 4 | goals4 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 9 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2011–2013 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 8 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2014– | nationalteam3 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps3 = 14 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 23:15, 2 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:15, 13 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Nathaniel Edwin Clyne''' (born 5 April 1991) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[right back]] for [[AFC Bournemouth]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from fellow {{English football updater|Liverpoo}} club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. He began his career at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], playing regularly in four [[EFL Championship|Championship]] seasons, before a move to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012, where he spent three seasons in the Premier League. He joined Liverpool in July 2015 for a fee of £12.5 million. Formerly an international at [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 level]], Clyne made his senior international debut for [[England national football team|England]] in November 2014. He was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016]]. ==Club career== ===Crystal Palace=== Clyne was born in [[Stockwell]], London. He made his first-team debut for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in a 3–0 [[EFL Championship|Championship]] win against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] at [[Selhurst Park]] on 18 October 2008.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7665071.stm |title=Crystal Palace 3–0 Barnsley |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 May 2010 |date=18 October 2008}} He signed a three-year professional contract with the club two days later, with manager [[Neil Warnock]] stating that Clyne "has a bright future in the game".{{cite news |url=http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/latestsport/Exclusive-Youngster-pens-year-deal/article-412991-detail/article.html |title=Youngster pens three-year deal |publisher=Croydon advertiser |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024203117/http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/latestsport/Exclusive-Youngster-pens-year-deal/article-412991-detail/article.html |archivedate=24 October 2008}} His first career goal came on 8 December 2009, when he opened a 4–2 win at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in the seventh minute.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8390609.stm "Reading 2–4 Crystal Palace"] BBC Sport. 8 December 2009. Retrieved 4 January 2014. In February 2010 he was offered a move to [[Premier League]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], but rejected it without even entering talks with manager [[Mick McCarthy]].{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_5909424,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Clyne snubs Wolves move |accessdate=19 July 2012 |date=1 February 2010}} In the 2010–11 season, Clyne was the youngest player in the Football League to play every single match of that campaign,{{cite web |title=First Team Profiles: Nathaniel Clyne |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/team/player-profile/nathaniel-clyne/2 |publisher=Southampton F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2014}} and won Crystal Palace's [[Crystal Palace F.C. Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] award.{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/may/cpfc-player-of-the-year---the-history/ |title=CPFC Player of the Year – The history |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2014 |date=6 May 2014}} ===Southampton=== [[File:Nathaniel Clyne (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Clyne playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012]] On 19 July 2012, Clyne signed a four-year deal with newly promoted Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2853579,00.html |publisher=Southampton F.C. |title=Saints Secure Clyne Deal |accessdate=1 July 2015 |date=19 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721232533/http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2853579,00.html |archivedate=21 July 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18890873 |title=Crystal Palace's Nathaniel Clyne seals Southampton move |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 July 2012 |date=19 July 2012}} He made his debut on 19 August, in a 3–2 defeat against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].{{cite news |last=Bevan |first=Chris |title=Man City 3–2 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19231354 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=19 August 2012}} His first match at [[St Mary's Stadium|St Mary's]] came six days later in a 0–2 defeat by [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].{{cite news |last=Monaghan |first=Matt |title=Southampton 0–2 Wigan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19304275 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=25 August 2012}} He scored his first goal for the club on 22 September, in a 4–1 win at home against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], set up by [[Gastón Ramírez]] with [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] coach [[Stuart Pearce]] in attendance at St Mary's.{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Aimee |title=Southampton 4–1 Aston Villa |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19615244 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=22 September 2012}} His second goal for the club came in the [[FA Cup]] third round against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 4 January 2014, opening an eventual 4–3 home victory with a 25-yard strike past [[Tom Heaton]].{{cite news |last=Cryer |first=Andy |title=Southampton 4–3 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25531713 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=4 January 2014}} Clyne scored in Southampton's first match of the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]], a 2–1 defeat against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 17 August.{{cite news |last=Ornstein |first=David |title=Liverpool 2–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730043 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=17 August 2014}} He scored his second goal of the campaign on 23 September, with a long-range effort which gave Southampton a 2–1 victory at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] third round.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29216769 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Arsenal 1–2 Southampton |accessdate=23 September 2014 |date=23 September 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/capital-one-cup/match/406142/arsenal-southampton/report |publisher=ESPN FC |title=Nathaniel Clyne's goal allows Southampton to see off Arsenal |accessdate=23 September 2014 |date=23 September 2014}} On 24 November, he finished [[Ryan Bertrand]]'s 81st-minute cross to earn a 1–1 draw away to Aston Villa.{{cite news |last=Rostance |first=Tom |title=Aston Villa 1–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30077226 |accessdate=24 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2014}} ===Liverpool=== ====2015–2019==== On 1 July 2015, Liverpool confirmed the signing of Clyne from Southampton for £12.5 million on a five-year contract, with his former club, Crystal Palace receiving a payment of £2.5M.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/187852-liverpool-sign-nathaniel-clyne |title=Liverpool sign Nathaniel Clyne |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=1 July 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33344772 |title=Nathaniel Clyne: Liverpool sign defender in £12.5m deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 July 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2015}} Clyne made his debut in a Liverpool shirt against the True Thai Premier League All Stars in [[Bangkok]] on 14 July as part of the club's pre-season tour.{{cite news |url=http://xtra.liverpoolfc.com/news/debuts-goals-and-a-monsoon-liverpool-players-react-on-twitter-to-bangkok-win |title=Debuts, goals and a monsoon – Liverpool players react on twitter to Bangkok win |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919023647/http://xtra.liverpoolfc.com/news/debuts-goals-and-a-monsoon-liverpool-players-react-on-twitter-to-bangkok-win |archivedate=19 September 2015 |deadurl=yes}} He made his competitive debut on 10 August in a 1–0 away win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the first match of the [[2015–16 Premier League]] season.{{cite news |title=Stoke 0–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33750574 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=10 August 2015 |date=9 August 2015}} On 8 October, Clyne scored his first Liverpool goal in a 1–0 [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]] fourth round victory over [[AFC Bournemouth]]; the team's first win under [[Jürgen Klopp]].{{cite news |title=Liverpool 1–0 Bournemouth |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34589602 |accessdate=28 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 October 2015}} His first league goal came on 14 February 2016, in a 6–0 win away to Aston Villa.{{cite news |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Aston Villa 0–6 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35515112 |accessdate=14 February 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 February 2016}} In March 2016, in Liverpool's first European matches against rivals [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], Clyne won a penalty that [[Daniel Sturridge]] converted in the first leg,{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Liverpool 2–0 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35763810 |accessdate=20 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 March 2016}} and conceded a penalty scored by [[Anthony Martial]] in the second, as Liverpool won 3–1 on aggregate in the last 16 of the [[UEFA Europa League]].{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Manchester United 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35815538 |accessdate=20 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 March 2016}} On 18 May, he played the full 90 minutes in the [[2016 UEFA Europa League Final|final]], a 3–1 loss to [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in [[Basel]].{{cite news |title=Sevilla make it three in row at Liverpool's expense |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000663/match=2017222/postmatch/report/index.html |accessdate=1 June 2016 |publisher=UEFA |date=18 May 2016}} Prior to the [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18 season]], Clyne suffered a back injury expected to rule him out until February 2018.{{cite news |last1=Critchley |first1=Mark |title=Liverpool defender Nathaniel Clyne set to miss next three months after operation on back injury |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/nathaniel-clyne-injury-liverpool-fc-news-latest-operation-back-a8052831.html |accessdate=23 January 2018 |work=The Independent |date=13 November 2017}} On 31 March 2018, having missed the entire campaign up to this point, he made his first appearance on the team sheet as an unused substitute in Liverpool's 2–1 league victory away to former club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43524303 |accessdate=31 March 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2018}} A week later on 7 April, he made his long-awaited return, keeping a clean sheet in a 0–0 draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in a [[Merseyside derby]] clash.{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Matt |title=Everton 0–0 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43602490 |accessdate=7 April 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 April 2018}} ====AFC Bournemouth (loan)==== Clyne joined Premier League club Bournemouth on 4 January 2019 on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2018–19 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2018–19 season]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46760201 |title=Nathaniel Clyne: Bournemouth sign Liverpool right-back on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2019 |accessdate=4 January 2019}} He made his debut on 5 January in a 3–1 FA Cup defeat by [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton and Hove Albion]].{{cite web |title=Bournemouth 1 Brighton 3 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46706811 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 January 2019 |date=5 January 2019}} ==International career== Clyne was born in England and is of Grenadian descent.{{cite news |last=Tweedale |first=Alistair |title=One in three players at Euro 2016 could play for another country |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/09/euro-2016-one-in-three-players-could-play-for-another-country/ |accessdate=17 March 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=9 June 2016}} On 2 October 2014, Clyne was named in the [[England national football team|England]] squad for the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|UEFA Euro 2016 qualifiers]] against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] later that month.{{cite news |title=England squad: Nathaniel Clyne and Jonjo Shelvey called up |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29460356 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 October 2014 |date=2 October 2014}} He was an unused substitute in both matches. Clyne said "My aim, now, is to try to make myself first choice for Euro 2016. That's what I'm going to keep pushing for."{{cite news |title=Nathaniel Clyne wants to make himself first choice right-back for England at Euro 2016 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/southamptons-nathaniel-clyne-wants-make-4610333 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=27 October 2015 |date=11 November 2014}} On 15 November, he made his full international debut in a home qualifier against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]], playing the full 90 minutes of a 3–1 victory.{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=England 3–1 Slovenia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29964707 |accessdate=15 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 November 2014}} Clyne went on to establish himself as first choice right back for England, appearing in five of their last six qualifiers.{{cite news |title=Euro 2016: Who will make England's starting XI in France? |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34506013 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=27 October 2015 |date=13 October 2015}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 2 February 2019}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL F.C. season|2009–10]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2009|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Championship |22||1||5||0||1||0||colspan=2|—||28||1 |- |[[2010–11 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2010–11]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2010|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Championship |46||0||1||0||2||0||colspan=2|—||49||0 |- |[[2011–12 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2011–12]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2011|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Championship |28||0||0||0||3||0||colspan=2|—||31||0 |- !colspan=2|Total !122||1||9||0||6||0||colspan=2|—||137||1 |- |rowspan=4|[[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] |[[2012–13 Southampton F.C. season|2012–13]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2012|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |[[Premier League]] |34||1||0||0||0||0||colspan=2|—||34||1 |- |[[2013–14 Southampton F.C. season|2013–14]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2013|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Premier League |25||0||3||1||1||0||colspan=2|—||29||1 |- |[[2014–15 Southampton F.C. season|2014–15]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2014|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Premier League |35||2||2||0||4||1||colspan=2|—||41||3 |- !colspan=2|Total !94||3||5||1||5||1||colspan=2|—||104||5 |- |rowspan=5|[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |[[2015–16 Liverpool F.C. season|2015–16]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2015|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Premier League |33||1||1||0||4||1||14{{efn|Appearances in [[UEFA Europa League]]}}||0||52||2 |- |[[2016–17 Liverpool F.C. season|2016–17]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2016|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Premier League |37||0||0||0||4||0||colspan=2|—||41||0 |- |[[2017–18 Liverpool F.C. season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|50127|2017|accessdate=4 January 2019}} |Premier League |3||0||0||0||0||0||0|2{{efn|Appearances in [[UEFA Champions League]]}}||0||5||0 |- |[[2018–19 Liverpool F.C. season|2018–19]] |Premier League |4||0||colspan=2|—||1||0||0||0||5||0 |- !colspan=2|Total !77||1||1||0||9||1||16||0||103||2 |- |[[AFC Bournemouth]] (loan) |[[2018–19 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2018–19]]{{Soccerbase season|50127|2018|accessdate=13 January 2019}} |Premier League |4||0||1||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||5||0 |- !colspan=3|Career total !296||5||16||1||20||2||16||0||348||8 |} {{notelist}} ===International=== {{updated|match played 15 November 2016}}{{NFT player |id=57697 |name=Clyne, Nathaniel |accessdate=13 January 2019}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by national team and year |- !National team!!Year!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=3|[[England national football team|England]] |2014||2||0 |- |2015||7||0 |- |2016||5||0 |- !colspan=2|Total||14||0 |} ==Honours== '''Liverpool''' *[[EFL Cup|Football League Cup]] runner-up: [[2015–16 Football League Cup|2015–16]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35624164 |title=Liverpool 1–1 Manchester City |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 February 2016 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} *[[UEFA Europa League]] runner-up: [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|2015–16]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36254631 |title=Liverpool 1–3 Sevilla |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 May 2016 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} *[[UEFA Champions League]] runner-up: [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League|2017–18]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44258022 |title=Real Madrid 3–1 Liverpool |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} '''Individual''' *[[PFA Team of the Year]]: [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 3|2011–12 Championship]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17797832 |title=Arsenal striker Robin van Persie named PFA Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=23 May 2018}} *[[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] Young Player of the Year: [[2008–09 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2008–09]], [[2009–10 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2009–10]] *[[Football League Awards|Football League]] Young Player of the Year: [[Football League Awards#2010 Awards|2010]] *[[UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] Technical Selection: [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Technical team selection|2010]] *[[Crystal Palace F.C. Player of the Year|Crystal Palace Player of the Year]]: [[2010–11 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2010–11]] *[[EFL Championship Player of the Month|Football League Championship Player of the Month]]: [[2011–12 Football League Championship#Monthly awards|October 2011]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[https://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/nathaniel-clyne Profile] at the Liverpool F.C. website *{{Soccerbase}} {{Navboxes | title = Awards | bg = gold | fg = navy | list1 = {{2011–12 Football League Championship PFA Team of the Year}} {{The Football League Young Player of the Year}} {{Crystal Palace F.C.
